node.title: MIT MOOSE workshop registration
node.bodyText:
Hey Guys,
Can anyone help me to check if I got registered successfully? I wanted to attend the workshop on Jan16th but I am not sure if I should have received another confirmation email. Below is the message that I got:
_Thank you for your interest in MOOSE Framework Fundamentals@MIT January 2024 scheduled for 01/16/2024 - 01/17/2024.
We have received your registration request and will pass this information on to the course coordinators.
Best Regards,
NCRC Staff_
Chen

Hello
Yes I have you in the list.
I must have sent the first information email just before you registered.
I will send an email again about the training soon
Guillaume

I am in the same boat. I have the same message, nothing more.
Can you send me the email about training as well?
Thanks,
Harsh Dudhatra
Hi Harsh can you send me your email please? You should be in I just didnt have you in the list when i sent the follow up

My email is hpd26@miami.edu
One of my batch mate, Abdulmohssen also registered for the workshop and didn't receive the conformational email.
His email id is: a.abaalkhail@umiami.edu
Thanks,
Harsh

node.title: Running the application gives an error that says "ComputeIsotropicElasticityTensor" is not a registered object even though I have enabled all the modules in the makefile.
node.bodyText:
Pretty much what the title says. I encountered this error and noticed that I had not enabled the makefile to have all the modules enabled so I quickly enabled them all and ran "make" again. It took a long time but went with no errors. I tried running my input file again and it still shows the same error.
All help will be super appreciated!

Hello
Can you please run ldd on the executable? If you are on Linux: ldd <executable-opt>
On Mac it s otool -L <executable-opt>
I want to check that the modules are indeed linked to the application. It can take a recompile to fix this if not
Guillaume

Super sorry for the late response. I am travelling.
Here I ran ldd:
`moose) devansh@devansh-VirtualBox:~/Desktop/moose-apps/thermal_sim$ ldd ./thermal_sim-opt

`

This looks correct.
Did you make cleanall after adding the new modules to your app?

No just ran make
Should I do that?

yup please. Either make cleanall
or save all your work then git clean -xfd then rebuild
this will take a while but I dont see the cause
Right. I'll report back very soon(still travelling) with the results.

I ran make cleanall which essentially deleted the already present executable from my application and then ran make again(which took like 2 hours). Now even after running  make and it having compiled everything successfully, no executable has been added to the working directory and when i try to run ./run_tests it fails.

The build failed.
Can you go build the combined executable in moose/modules and see if that succeeds?
Then if it does, can you make clean in your app (it should not remove the built moose modules, just your app) and make there
so you want me to go to moose/modules and run make there? and then if it succeeds run make clean in my application's directory?
yes

That worked!
Thank you so much. I love you guys!

node.title: Output overwrite after restart
node.bodyText:
Hi，
I output exodus and checkpoints of previous transient simulation, and restart the simulation with start_time set to end_time of previous simulation.
But the newly output exodus overwrites the previous results rather than to add after them.
Is there anyway to add newly calculated result after previous output?

Hello
I dont think we do.
@roystgnr you seen that before? Any way to append exodus data after the fact?
Guillaume

@GiudGiud Thanks for your reply.
I'm trying to couple my code with MOOSE framework, but wrapping it with MOOSE wrapping interface seems diffucult to me. I think that will need a comprehensive understand of MOOSE's framework.
I try to do the coupling in a file-base loose manner, which will need to restart MOOSE simulation multiple time when off-line data transfer, so I raise this question.
Back the exodus up everytime before restart would be a straight-forward way, while may need multiple backups when simulation time-steps are more.

In theory we've got support for this at the libMesh level: just set your_exii_writer.append(true) before doing ExodusII_IO::write_nodal_data() or ExodusII_IO::write_nodal_data_discontinuous().
In practice?  I've never used it ... but looking now, I do see MOOSE Exodus.C using it for recovery, so it must be working.  Might not be too much of a hassle to support it for non-recovery Exodus writes too.
@WayneX-Wong it does seem like a trivial change. Add a boolean parameter to the Exodus output class, and if that boolean is true then use the setter for appending.

@roystgnr @GiudGiud I follow what you suggest, add a boolean parameter and use _exodus_io_ptr->append(true) in Exodus::outputSetup() just as recovering do
But it gives a

Warning! The Exodus file already contains information records.
Exodus does not support writing additional records in this situation.

during run and overwrites again.

For the warning, you need to find the section in the code that writes the input file to the Exodus output. Then when appending, you should skip over that page.
If it is still overwriting the field data instead of appending, maybe we are still missing a call to ->append somewhere

I find this warning arising at exodusII_io_helper.C with following annotation

There may already be information records in the file (for example, if we're appending) and in that case, according to the Exodus documentation, writing more information records is not supported.

I don't know if this means I couldn't append Exodus in such case.
Thanks again for your guidance, I'll try more.

writing more information records is not supported.

writing fields for more timesteps should be supported
You might want to test your new append bool in the if statement in MOOSE Exodus.C that decides whether or not to call _exodus_io_ptr->write_information_records(_input_record);

You might want to test your new append bool in the if statement in MOOSE Exodus.C that decides whether or not to call _exodus_io_ptr->write_information_records(_input_record);

I  use setter of exodus_io->append here in and skip calling _exodus_io_ptr->write_information_records(_input_record) if append, the warning disappear but overwrite still
While now I found simply using --recover would realize appending... I've been obsessed with restarting
Thanks again for your patience @roystgnr @GiudGiud , hope I didn't take too much of your time

I've got to work on the moose training right now but I ll create an issue for this. And I should have time end of next week.
I think we can make it work for restart.

node.title: Registration for Moose Training session Jan 16-17 2024
node.bodyText: I want to register for the Moose training session which is being held on 16-17 Jan 2024 at MIT. But I do not find an option to register on the website. Who should be the point of contact regarding this? Also, does anyone know if the session is going to be recorded and will it be available to access later?

Hello
I'm the point of contact.
The session will not be recorded and is in-person only.
There are two full length training recordings available online already. While we will try to cover content differently in this January training, the existing recordings are good for use
Guillaume

Is there a way I can still register for the offline session on 16-17 Jan at MIT? I understand it's too late to ask for this now, but it will be very important to me to attend the sessions.
Thank you.

Are you in Massachusetts?
I can ask to re-open registration, should work

I am in University of Miami, Florida. But my Professor told me to apply for the training and book the tickets to Massachusetts. If registered, I assure that I will manage to reach Cambridge before time. I request you to please ask to re-open the registration.
Thanks.
I just emailed. I ll let you know soon
Registration should be re-opened now until tomorrow
Thank you so much for helping out. I just applied for the training. Looking forward to it.

node.title: Question about DFEM Method and Reaction Reigion Overflow Issue
node.bodyText:
Hello everyone,
I am currently employing the DFEM method to solve a problem involving multiple materials, each corresponding to a distinct block. While certain reaction types are exclusive to specific materials, I allocate reaction cross-sections for all reaction types to each material, setting the cross-section value to 0 for non-occurring reaction types.
An overflow issue in the output has arisen, as illustrated in the attached image. The image illustrates the occurrence region of a specific reaction type (highlighted in red), which appears larger than the theoretical region (covered in green).

Given that I am using AuxVariables to track reaction rates, and all operations in AuxKernels are based on quadrature points (_qp), I suspect the issue arises from the presence of quadrature points at the interfaces between different materials. These quadrature points belong to adjacent cells and possess properties of one adjacent material each. Although this doesn't impact the program's calculations, moose will merge data for quadrature points at the same location during output, resulting in non-zero reaction rates for adjacent cells.
I am using MONOMIAL variables of the first order, and I am unsure about the accuracy of my speculation. If it is, could you please provide guidance on how to address this situation?
Appreciate your assistance.
hityyds

Hello
This is an output problem I think. Higher order (discontinuous) elemental variables are mostly unsupported in exodus & visualization, as is discussed here #8635 (due to a string of issues, this issue dates but we have not addressed all of them)
You are visualizing a first MONOMIAL. Could you drop down to visualizing a constant monomial instead? This is well supported.
Guillaume

I followed your advice and used the CONSTANT variable to output the result, and indeed the overflow problem disappeared. However, may I ask, is this really a output problem? Have you previously attempted to test similar issues?
This is a common output problem. @YaqiWang might weigh in with his experience/suggestions for visualizing non constant discontinuous functions
I get it. Thank you for your reply.

node.title: Convergence Problem of "ConstantDT" for crystal plasticity model with finner mesh
node.bodyText:
Dear MOOSE experts,
The error occurs when I test the same CPFEM model with a finer mesh. For example, for 'substep.i', when I change the original 2x2x2 mesh to 4x4x4 mesh, the error message is shown below:
*** ERROR ***
The following error occurred in the object "ConstantDT", of type "ConstantDT".
Solve failed and timestep already at or below dtmin, cannot continue!
Similar issues happened to some other programs using Kalidindi's model. Would you happen to know the reason behind it? Can I fix it without decreasing the time step? Thanks!

Hello
This is an error due to the solve failing, so the time step gets reduced (or attempts to) and goes below the allowed minimum.
You can try to prevent the solve from failing, see this page:
https://mooseframework.inl.gov/moose/application_usage/failed_solves.html
Guillaume

node.title: Upcoming training for the New England region at MIT: MOOSE (Jan 16-17) & BISON (Jan 18-19)
node.bodyText:
The Idaho National Laboratory is providing a MOOSE training followed by a BISON training this January at MIT in Cambridge, MA.
For the MOOSE workshop on January 16-17:
MOOSE is an open-source finite element & finite volume framework developed by the DOE national laboratories that is the base for much of the advanced nuclear reactor modeling software. There are also several ongoing projects to develop MOOSE applications for fusion device modeling.
The Multiphysics Object Oriented Simulation Environment (MOOSE) Workshop provides an in-depth introduction to the framework. The course is two days in length and covers material starting from the mathematical underpinnings of the framework through advanced features of the MOOSE Multiapps system. The course uses a realistic multiphysics problem that is solved with increasing realism and complexity utilizing the many pluggable systems in the framework. Hands on exercises are supplied so attendees are encouraged to bring their own hardware to participate. More information about MOOSE can be found on our website.
The registration deadline will be flexible but we encourage early registration as space is limited. Please email me for any issue or question with registration.
For BISON workshop on January 18-19th:
The BISON fuel performance team is hosting a two-day, interactive workshop. This workshop is intended to help prospective users get started with the code, provide an overview of the methods to model specific fuel types, and provide practical examples to help users gain experience. Please forward this message to anyone at your institution interested in BISON, fuel performance modeling, or MOOSE-related software.
WORKSHOP TOPICS
•	Introduction to thermomechanical fuel performance modeling and multiphysics analysis
•	Code development principles and contribution of new models
•	Overview of LWR, TRISO, and Metallic fuel capabilities
•	Meshing fuel geometries
•	Simulation output analysis and visualization
•	Interactive practice examples and in-person support
The deadline for registration to the BISON workshop is December 1st, 2023. We encourage early registration as space is limited.
The sign-up link is at this address for both training. If you want to attend both, you must register twice, once for each training date.
https://ncrcaims.inl.gov/Identity/Account/TrainingRegistration
Hi, do you know when we will get confirmation that we have been accepted onto the workshops, I know the places are limited?

Hello
We are yet to process but I m pretty sure we will accept everyone
Guillaume

node.title: initQpStatefulProperties() for initial value setting

node.bodyText:
Hello
This should have been the way to do this.
How did you check that it's not working?
In your input file did you override the default for intiial_sum?
Guillaume

Thank you, Guillaume.
"VectorPostprocessors" prints: sum = 20, 40, 60, ... instead of 20.5, 40.4, 60.5, ...
I have set "initial_sum = 0.5" in the input file, too.
Do you have an example(s) of using initQpStatefulProperties()?
S. Thomas

In tensor mechanics I looked at PorosityFromStrain that uses a similar pattern.
Maybe you ll see what s different between the two

Thank you, Guillaume.
Could you be please more specific where I can find this example?
I cannot find it in /projects/moose/modules/tensor_mechanics/
S. Thomas
see /projects/moose/modules/tensor_mechanics/src/materials/PorosityFromStrain.C
Thank you, Guillaume! It is working now. :)

node.title: The crack surface density function
node.bodyText:
Hello,
Is there a way to extract the crack surface density (γ(d,∇d)  https://mooseframework.inl.gov/source/materials/ComputeLinearElasticPFFractureStress.html)?
You can write a postprocessor class to output the quantity.

Hi, I want to extract A(d) to be more precise, the crack surface integral over the whole volume, to measure the crack surface generated during the loading at the end of a test. I know that I can use postprocessor classes (such as ElementIntegralVariablePostprocessor) to integrate the variable gamma (the crack surface density) but where can I find the crack surface density that is function of the square of the gradient of d and also the local term function of d? Thanks!

node.title: initial conditions
node.bodyText:
Dear MOOSE experts,
I have finished calculating a task, and I want to calculate another task using the results of this task as initial conditions. What should I do? How do I modify the original input file?
input file.docx
Thank you.

Hello
Use either of these techniques:
https://mooseframework.inl.gov/application_usage/restart_recover.html
more likely you will want to use a Checkpoint restart as it is the safest / most widely applicable one. For a simple case, you may be able to restart from Exodus.
Guillaume
Okay, thank you.
